3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:29): It doesn't sound like a complex explanation to me - there's always a lot of known bugs and issues, which will be resolved over time, and any publication is necessarily a snapshot at a time when some have not yet been resolved
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:30): It'd be better if it didn't take six months to publish the next snapshot, though
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:30): In fact we could just take the limit as t->0 and not bother with snapshots at all
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:32): I don't think the W3C staff would appreciate having to go through the publication process for every CVS commit
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:33): and given the W3C's requirement that something is published regularly, the publication process can't be ignored entirely
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:33): but the published snapshots shouldn't lag so much behind the editors' drafts
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (16:36): published WDs are very important for people outside the W3C/WhatWG lookinh
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:37): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: All the people outside the process I have encountered have been horribly confused by the snapshots
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:37): since they are always out of date
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:38): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: Sure, I'm not suggesting that it would work with the current W3C rules
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:38): but presumably the rules are a means to an end rather than an end unto themselves
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (16:44): people outside the process want to get a signal "please look now", not following commits
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (16:44): also, they want something stable to comment on
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (16:44): that also means that a good moment to publish is when there was a significant change
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (16:45): therefore getting the change applied for ISSUE-1 and 2 would have been good
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:47): I would like some evidence to back up "people want"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:47): "good moment to publish" seems incompatible with heartbeat

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (16:54): planet: Is there a way to create a custom HTML validation schema for Visual Studio? <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2380346/is-there-a-way-to-create-a-custom-html-validation-schema-for-visual-studio>
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:56): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: The HTML WG already seems incompatible with heartbeat

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (16:59): Anyway, delaying an already-slow publication cycle for a good moment would be bad, but publishing regularly whenever there's a good moment would be good and better satisfy the heartbeat desires
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (17:03): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28, what you say people outside the process want does not at all meet my experience
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (17:04): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28, almost always the people asking me questions would've had no issue if they looked at the equivalent editor's draft
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:07): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: The overhead of doing a publication seems incompatible with a higher frequency, though
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:09): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Maybe increasing frequency would lower overhead
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:09): e.g. people wouldn't bother objecting to publication of the new draft, when it's not changed much since the draft that was published a month ago

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:11): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: That was roughly the original plan, but it turns out that people are confused into thinking that publication is somehow meaningful
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:11): and so fight tooth and nail for their changes to be taken before publication
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:12): even though the snapshot is useless
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:13): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: That seems like a positive feedback loop
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:13): People think publication is important, so they fight to delay it a bit and so it takes much longer
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:14): and since publication takes much longer, each snapshot hangs around for a long time and becomes more important

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:15): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: Apart from the bit about snapshots being more important (they are posibly percieved as more important but are actually less important the longer lived they are), that is exactly what has happened
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:15): So the solution is to break the loop by forcing a few quick publication cycles
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:16): and then people will realise it doesn't matter if this version isn't perfect, there'll be another version coming along soon
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:16): The loop could be broken by making publication strictly date based
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:16): But people wouldn't like that because it would be obvious that it is pointless
